data.title: Picture Puzzle
data.solution:
pieceSize, nPieces = map(int, input().split())
nColumns, nRows = map(int, input().split())
pictureWidth, pictureHeight = map(int, input().split())

from collections import defaultdict
borderToPieces = defaultdict(list)

import time
import sys

def log(*args):
    print(*args, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

id = 0
class Piece:
    def __init__(self, content):
        global id
        self.id = id
        id += 1
        self.content = content
        self.borders = [
            content[0],
            "".join(content[i][-1] for i in range(pieceSize)),
            content[pieceSize-1][::-1],
            "".join(content[i][0] for i in range(pieceSize - 1, -1, -1))
        ]
        self.orientation = None
    def getOrientedBorder(self, side):
        return self.borders[(side + 4 - self.orientation) % 4]
    def getOrientedContent(self):
        o = self.orientation
        pieceSize = len(self.content)
        return ["".join(self.content
            [i if o==0 else pieceSize-j-1 if o==1 else pieceSize-i-1 if o==2 else j]
            [j if o==0 else i if o==1 else pieceSize-j-1 if o==2 else pieceSize-i-1]
            for j in range(pieceSize)) for i in range(pieceSize)]
    def __repr__(self):
        return str(self.__dict__)
    def __str__(self):
        return repr(self)

pieces = []

for _ in range(nPieces):
    piece = Piece([input() for _ in range(pieceSize)])
    for i, border in enumerate(piece.borders):
        borderToPieces[border].append((piece, i))
    pieces.append(piece)

emptyBorder = "#" * pieceSize

nIterations = 0
nDeadEnds = 0

grid = [[None for _ in range(nColumns)] for _ in range(nRows)]
solutions = []
def search(i, j):
    global solutions
    global nIterations
    global nDeadEnds
    nIterations += 1
    j += 1
    if j >= nColumns:
        j = 0
        i += 1
    if i >= nRows:
        newSolution = [[None for _ in range(pictureWidth)] for _ in range(pictureHeight)]
        for i in range(nRows):
            for j in range(nColumns):
                content = grid[i][j].getOrientedContent()
                for i2 in range(pieceSize):
                    for j2 in range(pieceSize):
                        newSolution[i * (pieceSize - 1) + i2][j * (pieceSize - 1) + j2] = content[i2][j2]
        # Register the solution only if it was not already found
        for solution in solutions:
            if all(newRow == row for newRow, row in zip(newSolution, solution)):
                break
        else:
            solutions.append(newSolution)
        return True
    leftBorder = emptyBorder if j == 0 else grid[i][j - 1].getOrientedBorder(1) # right border of piece on left side
    topBorder = emptyBorder if i == 0 else grid[i - 1][j].getOrientedBorder(2) # bottom border of piece on top side
    matches = []
    for piece, orientation in borderToPieces[topBorder[::-1]]: # for each piece matching the top border
        if piece.orientation is not None:
            continue # chech that this piece is not placed yet
        # rotate the piece in order to face the top border
        pieceOrientation = (4 - orientation) % 4
        if piece.id == 0 and pieceOrientation != 0:
            continue # chech that the first piece has the right orientation
        if piece.borders[(orientation + 3) % 4][::-1] != leftBorder:
            continue # check the left border
        if j == nColumns - 1 and piece.borders[(orientation + 1) % 4] != emptyBorder:
            continue # check that right border is empty if on the last column
        if i == nRows - 1 and piece.borders[(orientation + 2) % 4] != emptyBorder:
            continue # check that bottom border is empty if on the last row
        matches.append((piece, pieceOrientation))
    for piece, orientation in matches:
        piece.orientation = orientation
        grid[i][j] = piece
        solutionFound = search(i, j)
        # Following line is commented to display the total number of dead ends
        #if solutionFound: return True
        grid[i][j] = None
        piece.orientation = None
    if len(matches) == 0:
        nDeadEnds += 1
    return False

start = time.time()
search(0, -1)
log("Duration:", time.time() - start)
log("Iterations:", nIterations)
log("Dead ends:", nDeadEnds)
log("Solutions:", len(solutions))

for solution in solutions:
    for row in solution:
        print("".join(row))
data.statement:
What if you have to solve a real puzzle? I mean, assembling pieces of a picture into a single big picture. You are provided a set of puzzle pieces, in a random order and with random orientations. You have to assemble the final picture from the pieces.

<<Assembly Rules:>>
Two pieces can be put together if a border of the first piece matches with a border of the second one. That is, the given pieces have their border "duplicated". Only then do they match. This duplicated border appears only once in the final picture. For example, assembling the two pieces below results in the picture on the right:

`{{####}}     {{####}}     {{#######}}
{{#123}}  +  {{345#}}  =  {{#12345#}}
{{#abc}}     {{cde#}}     {{#abcde#}}
{{####}}     {{####}}     {{#######}}`
However, the pieces are given with random orientations (in 90 degree steps, that is, 4 different orientations). In the example below the right border of the 1st piece matches the top border of the 2nd piece, so the 2nd piece needs to be rotated before assembling:

`{{####}}     {{#c3#}}     {{#######}}
{{#123}}  +  {{#d4#}}  =  {{#12345#}}
{{#abc}}     {{#e5#}}     {{#abcde#}}
{{####}}     {{####}}     {{#######}}`

<<Guarantees:>>
• The border of a piece which is on the border of the final picture will contain only the '#' character.
• The first piece (in the input list) is given with the correct orientation so that you can know the orientation of the whole picture.
• There is only one solution with the given rules and the given pieces.


<<Notes:>>
• With the given assembly rules, you can determine that if the puzzle is composed of [[nColumns]] columns and [[nRows]] rows of pieces with size [[pieceSize]], then the final picture will have [[pictureWidth]] columns and [[pictureHeight]] rows of characters, where

==> [[pictureWidth]] = {{1 + (}}[[pieceSize]] {{- 1) * }}[[nColumns]]

==> [[pictureHeight]] = {{1 + (}}[[pieceSize]] {{- 1) * }}[[nRows]]

• The given constraints are designed so that you can use a brute-force solution with exponential complexity (but still not too silly :p).
• The first four test cases give the pieces without rotation. So you can first try to find a solution that doesn't take into account the rotated pieces.
• Be aware that multiple pieces might be identical. However because of the unicity of the solution, pieces cannot have same borders and different contents. For example, in the same puzzle, you will never have two pieces like :
`{{123}}     {{123}}
{{8A4}} and {{8B4}}
{{765}}     {{765}}`because they could be swapped and the puzzle would have multiple solutions.


<<Test descriptions:>>
`Name    |Pieces|Piece size|Ambiguity|Rotation|Comment
--------|------|----------|---------|--------|-------------------------------------
 Test 1 | 2x2  | 4x4      | No      | No     | Who needs an algo to solve that?
 Test 2 | 15x15| 2x2      | No      | No     | So much diversity
 Test 3 | 11x3 | 6x6      | A bit   | No     | The birth of programming languages
 Test 4 | 8x4  | 6x6      | More    | No     | Your deepest wish
 Test 5 | 2x2  | 4x4      | No      | Yes    | Who needs an algo to solve that?
 Test 6 | 15x15| 2x2      | No      | Yes    | So much diversity
 Test 7 | 11x3 | 6x6      | A bit   | Yes    | The birth of programming languages
 Test 8 | 8x4  | 6x6      | More    | Yes    | Your deepest wish`

testCases.testOut:
########################################################
#  Python: What if everything was a dict?              #
#  Java: What if everything was an object?             #
#  JS: What if everything was a dict and an object?    #
#  C: What if everything was a pointer?                #
#  LISP: What if everything was a pair?                #
#  Scheme: What if everything was a function?          #
#  Haskell: What if everything was a monad?            #
#  Assembly: What if everything was a register?        #
#  COBOL: WHAT IF EVERYTHING WAS UPPERCASE?            #
#  C#: What if everything was like Java but different? #
#  Ruby: What if everything was monkey patched?        #
#  C++: What if we added everything to the language?   #
#  C++11: What if we forgot to stop adding stuff?      #
#  Rust: What if garbage collection didn't exist?      #
########################################################

#  Python: What if everything was a dict?              #
#  Java: What if everything was an object?             #
#  JS: What if everything was a dict and an object?    #
#  C: What if everything was a pointer?                #
#  LISP: What if everything was a pair?                #
#  Scheme: What if everything was a function?          #
#  Haskell: What if everything was a monad?            #
#  Assembly: What if everything was a register?        #
#  COBOL: WHAT IF EVERYTHING WAS UPPERCASE?            #
#  C#: What if everything was like Java but different? #
#  Ruby: What if everything was monkey patched?        #
#  C++: What if we added everything to the language?   #
#  C++11: What if we forgot to stop adding stuff?      #
#  Rust: What if garbage collection didn't exist?      #
########################################################

testCases.testOut:
########################################################
#  Python: What if everything was a dict?              #
#  Java: What if everything was an object?             #
#  JS: What if everything was a dict and an object?    #
#  C: What if everything was a pointer?                #
#  LISP: What if everything was a pair?                #
#  Scheme: What if everything was a function?          #
#  Haskell: What if everything was a monad?            #
#  Assembly: What if everything was a register?        #
#  COBOL: WHAT IF EVERYTHING WAS UPPERCASE?            #
#  C#: What if everything was like Java but different? #
#  Ruby: What if everything was monkey patched?        #
#  C++: What if we added everything to the language?   #
#  C++17: What if we forgot to stop adding stuff?      #
#  Rust: What if garbage collection didn't exist?      #
########################################################

data.constraints:
• 2 ≤ [[pieceSize]] ≤ 6
• 2 ≤ [[nColumns]] ≤ 15
• 2 ≤ [[nRows]] ≤ 15
• 4 ≤ [[nPieces]] ≤ 225
• 2 ≤ [[pictureHeight]] ≤ 60
• 2 ≤ [[pictureWidth]] ≤ 60
• There is only one solution with the given rules and the given pieces.
• The first piece given will always be in the correct orientation.
data.stubGenerator:
read pieceSize:int nPieces:int
read nColumns:int nRows:int
read pictureWidth:int pictureHeight:int
loop nPieces loop pieceSize read row:string(pieceSize)

loop pictureHeight write row of the picture composed of pictureWidth characters

INPUT
pieceSize: size of a piece (its width and its height)
nColumns: number of pieces in a row of the picture
nRows: number of pieces in a column of the picture
nPieces: number of pieces (= nColumns * nRows)
pictureWidth: number of characters in a row of the picture (= 1 + nColumns * (pieceSize - 1))
pictureHeight: number of characters in a column of the picture (= 1 + nRows * (pieceSize - 1))
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Two space-separated integers: [[pieceSize]] the size of a square-shaped piece (number of characters on every border of the piece) and [[nPieces]] the total number of pieces given in the input.

<<Line 2:>> Two space-separated integers: [[nColumns]] the number of pieces in a row, [[nRows]] the number of pieces in a column in the final picture.

<<Line 3:>> Two space-separated integers: [[pictureWidth]] the number of characters in a row of the final picture, [[pictureHeight]] the number of characters in a column of the final picture.

<<Next [[nPieces]]x[[pieceSize]] lines:>> All the pieces. each piece is [[pieceSize]] lines composed of [[pieceSize]] characters.
data.outputDescription: [[pictureHeight]] lines of [[pictureWidth]] characters representing the final picture

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

What if you have to solve a real puzzle? I mean, assembling pieces of a picture into a single big picture. You are provided a set of puzzle pieces, in a random order and with random orientations. You have to assemble the final picture from the pieces.

Assembly Rules:
Two pieces can be put together if a border of the first piece matches with a border of the second one. That is, the given pieces have their border "duplicated". Only then do they match. This duplicated border appears only once in the final picture. For example, assembling the two pieces below results in the picture on the right:

####     ####     #######
#123  +  345#  =  #12345#
#abc     cde#     #abcde#
####     ####     #######

However, the pieces are given with random orientations (in 90 degree steps, that is, 4 different orientations). In the example below the right border of the 1st piece matches the top border of the 2nd piece, so the 2nd piece needs to be rotated before assembling:

####     #c3#     #######
#123  +  #d4#  =  #12345#
#abc     #e5#     #abcde#
####     ####     #######


Guarantees:
• The border of a piece which is on the border of the final picture will contain only the '#' character.
• The first piece (in the input list) is given with the correct orientation so that you can know the orientation of the whole picture.
• There is only one solution with the given rules and the given pieces.


Notes:
• With the given assembly rules, you can determine that if the puzzle is composed of nColumns columns and nRows rows of pieces with size pieceSize, then the final picture will have pictureWidth columns and pictureHeight rows of characters, where

==> pictureWidth = 1 + (pieceSize - 1) * nColumns

==> pictureHeight = 1 + (pieceSize - 1) * nRows

• The given constraints are designed so that you can use a brute-force solution with exponential complexity (but still not too silly :p).
• The first four test cases give the pieces without rotation. So you can first try to find a solution that doesn't take into account the rotated pieces.
• Be aware that multiple pieces might be identical. However because of the unicity of the solution, pieces cannot have same borders and different contents. For example, in the same puzzle, you will never have two pieces like :
123     123
8A4 and 8B4
765     765
because they could be swapped and the puzzle would have multiple solutions.


Test descriptions:
Name    |Pieces|Piece size|Ambiguity|Rotation|Comment
--------|------|----------|---------|--------|-------------------------------------
 Test 1 | 2x2  | 4x4      | No      | No     | Who needs an algo to solve that?
 Test 2 | 15x15| 2x2      | No      | No     | So much diversity
 Test 3 | 11x3 | 6x6      | A bit   | No     | The birth of programming languages
 Test 4 | 8x4  | 6x6      | More    | No     | Your deepest wish
 Test 5 | 2x2  | 4x4      | No      | Yes    | Who needs an algo to solve that?
 Test 6 | 15x15| 2x2      | No      | Yes    | So much diversity
 Test 7 | 11x3 | 6x6      | A bit   | Yes    | The birth of programming languages
 Test 8 | 8x4  | 6x6      | More    | Yes    | Your deepest wish
Input
Line 1: Two space-separated integers: pieceSize the size of a square-shaped piece (number of characters on every border of the piece) and nPieces the total number of pieces given in the input.

Line 2: Two space-separated integers: nColumns the number of pieces in a row, nRows the number of pieces in a column in the final picture.

Line 3: Two space-separated integers: pictureWidth the number of characters in a row of the final picture, pictureHeight the number of characters in a column of the final picture.

Next nPiecesxpieceSize lines: All the pieces. each piece is pieceSize lines composed of pieceSize characters.
Output
pictureHeight lines of pictureWidth characters representing the final picture
Constraints
• 2 ≤ pieceSize ≤ 6
• 2 ≤ nColumns ≤ 15
• 2 ≤ nRows ≤ 15
• 4 ≤ nPieces ≤ 225
• 2 ≤ pictureHeight ≤ 60
• 2 ≤ pictureWidth ≤ 60
• There is only one solution with the given rules and the given pieces.
• The first piece given will always be in the correct orientation.
Example
Input
4 4
2 2
7 7
+ B#
  *#
C**#
####
####
#**A
#*  
#D +
####
A**#
  *#
+ B#
#D +
#*  
#**C
####
Output
#######
#**A**#
#*   *#
#D + B#
#*   *#
#**C**#
#######
